repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

body: Hi! We would like to work on this issue :)
cool, you might also look into the draft PR #1222

Hi!
We are about to start to implement our Kalman filter, we have done quite a bit of research about the filter and have a few questions about the usage and implementation. 
There are several matrices needed to make the calculations for the Kalman filter: 
Q - process noise matrix 
R - measurement noise matrix 
A/F - state transition matrix 
B/G - control matrix
Should these matrices be user inputs for the constructor? 

We also found that for efficient smoothing effect it is important to have a strong initial guess of X - estimated system state and P - covariance matrix (X0, P0).  
Is there a way to create them in an efficient way for the use of the filter? We found one way but it seems to be inefficient and long. Should we leave the option for user input for X and P as well?
Also, how would you like us to take care of the case where there is missing measurements in the data? Is this something we should take into account?

@lielleravid, I think optimally the user can choose which of these matrices are user input and which are estimated, with a default of estimation.
I would also advise to start with investigating potential packages that could be interfaced here - Kalman filters are not uncommon, although I do not have a full view of what is out there.

@lielleravid You might want to check the implementation in [FilterPy](https://filterpy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/). It is typical that the noice matrices Q and R are specified by the user since they depend on the considered system.

rename.from: Implement Kálmán filter - transformer (with update functionality)
rename.to: [ENH] Implement Kálmán filter - transformer (with update functionality)

body: Yes, @lielleravid and @NoaBenAmi are both working on this currently, and looking at `filterpy` and `pykalman` to interface. One of the two (I forgot which) has more capability to estimate the various matrices.

issue.title: [ENH] Kalman filter - transformers

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->
#### Reference Issues/PRs

https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1011

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
I have created two Kalman filter transformers, interfacing python libraries `pykalman` and `FilterPy`. 

#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

python libraries `pykalman` and `FilterPy`. 

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

Adaptation of `sktime` coding standards and suggestions for improving code quality.

#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [x] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [x] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [x] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.
- [x] The PR title starts with either [ENH], [DOC] or [BUG] indicating whether the PR topic is related to enhancement, documentation or bug

##### For new estimators
- [x] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

issue.title: [MENTEE] Noa Ben Ami
issue.body:
**Mentee:** 
Noa Ben Ami


**Mentors:**
@fkiraly, @lmmentel, @Lovkush-A 
  

**Why did you join sktime's mentorship program?**
I joined the mentorship program as part of a final seminar for my B.Sc. degree in Software Engineering.
My goals for the Seminar -

- Contributing several algorithms to sktime
- Understand the design and architecture of sktime 
- Taking part in a CI/CD open-source community

The mentoring program is a great way to achieve all of the above.


**What topics are you working on?**
**Kalman Filter**
The Kalman Filter is an unsupervised algorithm consisting of several mathematical equations which are used to create an estimate of the state of a process.
Kalman Filter can be used as a Transformer or a Forecaster, and I’ve been working on integrating both estimators into sktime. 
Transformer -
[issue](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/1011), [PR](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/2611), [merged code](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/blob/main/sktime/transformations/series/kalman_filter.py). 
Forecaster -
[issue](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/2819), [draft PR](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/pull/2853) 
**Semantic Segmentation algorithms** 
FLUSS (Fast Low-cost Unipotent Semantic Segmentation) and FLOSS (Fast Low-cost Online Semantic Segmentation) are “semantic segmentation” algorithms that divide a time series into internally consistent homogenous regions called regimes.
[FLUSS issue](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/2868), [FLOSS issue](https://github.com/sktime/sktime/issues/2820).


**What are your learning goals?**
- Learning about collaborative coding practices
- Deepen my knowledge in machine learning algorithms for time series
- Improve my coding skills by using aspects of software engineering.

**What's next for you after the mentorship program?**
<!-- Thanks for participating! -->
